Pre-Game Insights: The Oklahoma City Thunder are riding a franchise-record 14-game winning streak, while the Celtics are the defending NBA champions.
The Thunder have trailed each of the last three games by at least 12 points before coming back to win, including overcoming a 14-point deficit in Friday's 117-107 home win over the Knicks.
The Thunder are amid a four-game stretch against the top three teams from the Eastern Conference.
Oklahoma City is 10-0 against the Eastern Conference, though it fell to Milwaukee in the NBA Cup final that doesn’t count in the regular-season standings.
The Celtics enter Sunday's game on a three-game winning streak, with the last two coming to start a four-game road trip.

During the winning streak, the Celtics are shooting 51.6 percent from the floor and have posted a 133.6 offensive rating — points scored per 100 possessions — and a 103.3 defensive rating. Both marks are best in the NBA over that span.
Oklahoma City has the NBA's best defense, with a 102.9 defensive rating.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Shai Gilgeous-Alexander is averaging 32.7 points, 5.2 assists, 5.2 rebounds, 2.3 steals and 1.2 blocks during the Thunder's winning streak.
Jalen Williams is making a case for an All-Star berth.
Aaron Wiggins scored 15 fourth-quarter points to key the Thunder's comeback in Friday's game, while Isaiah Hartenstein had a handful of critical plays at both ends down the stretch.

Porzingis returned Friday after missing four games with a left ankle sprain, while Jaylen Brown has missed the last two games with a shoulder strain and Al Horford figures to return Sunday after missing Friday's win due to rest on the second night of a back-to-back.
Others: The Thunder have shown it can win in a variety of ways.
The Celtics are trying to get back to their identity of who they are on both ends of the floor after December didn't go the way they wanted to.
